Great points from both,  this has really helped me pull apart the issues 
I was haivng and solve my Restful representation dilema for the three 
cases I provided earlier. Most of my issues were coming from the browser 
(web-techie) side of the equation where I wanted to do composition and 
needed some precision that I couldn't rely on precisely enough from 
content negotiation.

thanks

Jeff

Jeoff Wilks wrote:

> All good points, Jon. If Jeff is looking to guarantee that some 
> clients receive an HTML representation, others an XML representation, 
> etc. (without relying on content negotiation) then it is appropriate 
> to use the direct URIs for each desired variant.
>
>
> On 10/17/05, *Jon Hanna* <jon@... 
> <mailto:jon@...>> wrote:
>
>     Jeoff Wilks wrote:
>     > Hey Jeff,
>     >
>     > I also struggled with the same issue you have. One thing I
>     noticed while
>     > reading through the Apache docs on content negotiation is that,
>     though
>     > you can request a resource for which multiple representations
>     exist, you
>     > can also request a specific variant using its exact URI. Look at the
>     > table at the bottom of this web page for examples:
>     > http://httpd.apache.org/docs/1.3/content-negotiation.html
>     <http://httpd.apache.org/docs/1.3/content-negotiation.html>
>     >
>     > Building on the example from that web page, assume you have a
>     resource
>     > "foo" for which various representations exist.
>     >
>     > /foo
>     > /foo.html
>     > /foo.xml
>     > /foo.rss
>
>     To my mind /foo.html should not be considered as a URI for the same
>     resources as /foo
>
>     /foo.html is suitable when the resource you are interested is the HTML
>     representation of /foo in and off itself. GET /foo says "let me know
>     about foo" GET /foo.html says "let me know about the HTML document you
>     happen to be using to represent /foo".
>
>     One would hope that outside of web-techies more users of the system
>     would be interested in /foo than in /foo.html
>
>
>
>
